title: Formatting
text:
In text paragraphs, code is always formatted with a monospace font and surrounded by a box like this. Longer examples of code will be in a separate box.

Pressing a KeyKey on the keyboard is formatted like that.

title: Loop Invariants
text:
What Big-\(O\) Actually Tells Us
Consider \(T(n) = 3n^2 + 5n + 7\). What happens when \(n\) doubles?







The ratio approaches 4. Always. For ANY quadratic.
â€œThe constant 3, the +5n, the +7 â€” none of them matter. Doubling n â†’ quadrupling T(n). Thatâ€™s what \(O(n^2)\) means.â€

title: Loop Invariants
text:
The Doubling Test



Class
When \(n\) doubles, timeâ€¦




\(O(1)\)
stays the same


\(O(\log n)\)

doubles

slightly more than doubles

squares (!!)




â€œThis is what Big-O tells us: the SHAPE of growth, not the exact numbers.â€

title: Loop Invariants
Loop Invariants
text:
\(O(2^n)\): Exponential
def all_subsets(arr):
    if not arr:
        return [[]]
    rest = all_subsets(arr[1:])
    return rest + [[arr[0]] + s for s in rest]







â€œDoubles with each element.â€
n=50: more operations than atoms in a grain of sand. n=100: more operations than atoms in the observable universe.
At 1 billion ops/sec, n=100 would take \(10^{21}\) years â€” heat death of universe.
â€œOften intractable. Weâ€™ll see NP-completeness in Week 12.â€

text:
The Setup

title: Loop Invariants
text:
The Race







â€œWeâ€™re testing worst case: no duplicates, so both algorithms scan everything.â€
â€œWhat do you notice?â€
\(\Theta(n^2)\): 4Ã— slower when n doubles â€” thatâ€™s quadratic! \(\Theta(n)\): barely changes â€” thatâ€™s linear!
â€œThe set gives \(O(1)\) lookup â€” transforms \(\Theta(n^2)\) into \(\Theta(n)\).â€

title: Loop Invariants
text:
What Happened
Worst case: \(\Theta(n^2) \to \Theta(n)\)
The set provides \(O(1)\) lookup.

â€œThis is the power of data structures. Weâ€™ll learn how sets work in Week 5.â€
â€œBoth bounds are tight. Weâ€™re not hedging â€” we analyzed the worst case and know exactly how it scales.â€

title: Loop Invariants
text:
The Crossover







â€œAt small n, constants dominate. The â€˜\(O(1)\)â€™ algorithm with 10ms overhead is slower!â€
Live demo: add larger n values (10000, 100000, 1000000) to show the crossover where linear catches up and passes.

Python loop: large constants (interpreter overhead)

title: What Makes an Algorithm Good?
text:
Whatâ€™s this course about?

Pause. Let them guess. Theyâ€™ll say â€œdata structuresâ€, â€œalgorithmsâ€, â€œefficiencyâ€â€¦

title: What Makes an Algorithm Good?
text:
Course Goals

Become familiar with fundamental data structures and algorithms

Learn when to use them

Improve your ability to solve problems abstractly

Data structures and algorithms are the building blocks

Improve your ability to analyze algorithms

Prove correctness
Gauge, compare, and improve time and space complexity

Develop Python fluency for implementing solutions


â€œWhich of these is different from your other courses?â€
Theyâ€™ll identify â€œanalyze algorithms.â€ â€œWhat does â€˜analyzeâ€™ mean?â€

title: What Makes an Algorithm Good?
text:
Algorithm Analysis
What does it mean to analyze an algorithm?

Let them generate ideas. Theyâ€™ll say: â€œsee if it worksâ€, â€œhow fastâ€, â€œhow much memoryâ€â€¦
Then reveal: correctness, time complexity, space complexity.
â€œThis is THE frame for the entire course.â€

title: What Makes an Algorithm Good?
text:
Correctness

What does it mean for an algorithm to be correct?

Â 

If an algorithm is not correct, is its value 0?


Discussion. Then ask:
Let them debate. Plant seeds: - Approximation (close enough) - Heuristics (usually right) - Probabilistic (correct with high probability)
â€œWeâ€™ll learn to prove correctness in Week 2.â€
SEED PLANTED for Week 5 (hash tables) and Week 12 (NP-hardness).

title: What Makes an Algorithm Good?
text:
Efficiency
Once we know itâ€™s correctâ€¦

How long does it take?
How much memory does it use?


â€œThis week: efficiency. Next week: proving correctness.â€
Notice that these two things are related â€“ if you use a lot of memory, you WILL spend a long time writing to that memory!

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
The Two Pillars

Correctness â€” Does it work?
Efficiency â€” How fast?


â€œLast week: efficiency. This week: we add correctness.â€

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
The Analysis Recipe

Establish the case â€” usually worst case
Analyze the function â€” count operations for that case
State the bound:

\(\Theta\) (or â€œtight \(O\)â€) if you know itâ€™s exact
\(O\) if youâ€™re only claiming an upper bound
\(\Omega\) if youâ€™re only claiming a lower bound



â€œWhen we say â€˜binary search is \(O(\log n)\)â€™ we mean itâ€™s tight â€” \(\Theta(\log n)\). Weâ€™re not hedging.â€
â€œFirst: which case? Then: whatâ€™s the function? Then: is it tight or just a bound?â€

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
Big-\(O\) is a Set
\(O(g(n))\) is the set of all functions \(f(n)\) satisfying the definition.
\[O(n) = \{f(n) : \exists c > 0, n_0 \geq 0 \text{ such that } f(n) \leq c \cdot n \text{ for all } n \geq n_0\}\]

â€œFrom discrete math: Big-O defines a SET of functions.â€

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
The Ladder
\[O(1) \subset O(\log n) \subset O(n) \subset O(n \log n) \subset O(n^2) \subset O(2^n)\]
Each class contains all the ones to its left.

â€œEvery \(O(1)\) function is also \(O(n)\), also \(O(n^2)\), etc.â€

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
A Common Abuse of Notation
We write: \(\quad 4n + 2 = O(n)\)
We mean: \(\quad 4n + 2 \in O(n)\)

â€œYouâ€™ll see this everywhere. Just remember: weâ€™re really talking about set membership.â€

title: The Hierarchy of Speed
text:
True or False?

\(3n + 2 \in O(n)\)
\(3n + 2 \in O(n^2)\)
\(n^2 \in O(n)\)
\(5 \in O(1)\)
\(5 \in O(n)\)


T, T, F, T, T
â€œIf \(f \in O(g)\) and \(O(g) \subset O(h)\), then \(f \in O(h)\).â€
â€œLetâ€™s see what these mean at scale.â€

title: Analysis
text:
The Definition of Big-O
\(f(n)\) is \(O(g(n))\) if there exist constants \(c > 0\) and \(n_0 \geq 0\) such that:
\[f(n) \leq c \cdot g(n) \quad \text{for all } n \geq n_0\]










â€œIn words: f grows no faster than g, once n is big enough.â€

title: Analysis
text:
Other Definitions
\(f(n)\) is \(O(g(n))\) if there exist constants \(c > 0\) and \(n_0 \geq 0\) such that:
\[f(n) \leq c \cdot g(n) \quad \text{for all } n \geq n_0\]
\(f(n)\) is \(\Omega(g(n))\) if there exist constants \(c > 0\) and \(n_0 \geq 0\) such that:
\[f(n) \geq c \cdot g(n) \quad \text{for all } n \geq n_0\]
\(f(n)\) is \(\Theta(g(n))\) iff it is both \(O(g(n))\) and \(\Omega(g(n))\).

â€œWe mostly use O, though we usually mean Î˜.â€

\[1 + 2 + 3 + \ldots + n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\]

â€œThis is \(O(n^2)\), not \(O(n)\).â€
Whenever you see â€œall pairsâ€ â€” expect quadratic.

title: Lab: Create your own website!
text:
We are going to create a website using a Quarto. Quarto documents are a mix of natural language and executed code and this pattern is called literate programming. A Quarto document usually contains:

Text formatted in Markdown.
Code is fenced as code chunk between ```{r} and ```.
Metadata as YAML with the format key: value. You can find metadata in the header of the document fenced by ---, or in code chunks starting with #|.

---
title: "Untitled"
format: html
---

## Quarto

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into
a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see <https://quarto.org>.

```{r}
#| label: calculation

1 + 1
```

title: Welcome to DSCI 221!
text:
Welcome to DSCI 221: Data Structures and Algorithms for Data Science!
In this course, weâ€™ll explore how the right data structure can turn an impossible problem into a trivial one. From the magic of hash tables (how does Shazam identify a song in milliseconds?) to graph algorithms (whatâ€™s the cheapest flight to Tokyo?), youâ€™ll develop the algorithmic thinking that separates good programmers from great ones.
Getting started:

Read the syllabus for course policies and requirements
Check the schedule on the home page to see whatâ€™s coming up
Come to class ready to think about puzzles!

See you in class!

title: Setup: Tech stack
text:
As with any computer science or data science course, several tools and software packages are needed for this course. These tools are not used by the typical consumer, so most Windows or macOS installations will not include them. Even on machines which do include them (such as many Linux distributions), they may still need some configuration. Below you will find guides to install the tech stack for DSCI 221, with different guides for different operating systems. A tech stack is the complete set of tools and technologies needed to accomplish a particular task; in this case, it is the various programming and data analytics that we will explore in DSCI 221.
As you go through the install guides, remember that perhaps the two most important things you will learn in this course is how to troubleshoot things and achieve familiarity and proficiency with your computer. Be patient, read things carefully, do not be afraid to try things, itâ€™s unlikely you will do anything to irreversibly break your computer! Almost everything you do (youâ€™re on your own if you decide to take a hammer to your laptop!) can be undone, donâ€™t be afraid to ask your peers, TAs, and the instructor on Giscus below (you will need to set up an GitHub account first).
This is an exciting time for you as you begin your Software Development journey!

title: Setup: Tech stack
text:
Hardware
Before starting, ensure that your laptop meets the minimum requirements:

Can connect to networks via a wireless connection.
Has at least 25 GB disk space available.
Has at least 4 GB of RAM (more is recommended).
Uses a 64-bit CPU.
Is at most 6 years old at the start of the course (4 years old or newer is recommended).
Student user has full administrative access to the computer.







Important



If your computer does not meet any of the requirements above, please donâ€™t just drop the course!! Let me know first and we can discuss alternate possibilities so you can still take the course.

title: Setup: Tech stack
text:
Software






Tip



These installation notes assume you are starting with a fresh install, without any custom setups. Following the instructions below will help you install and configure the tech stack correctly in the same way for our course, enabling us to support you effectively and minimize setup issues and software conflicts.



WindowsmacOS


 In all the sections below, if you are presented with the choice to download either a 64-bit (also called x64) or a 32-bit (also called x86) version of the application always choose the 64-bit version.


In all the sections below, if you are presented with the choice to download either a 64-bit (also called x64) or a 32-bit (also called x86) version of the application always choose the 64-bit version. If you purchased a Mac anytime in the last few years, chances are you have an â€œM1/M2/M3/M4â€â€¦ Mac, also known as â€œApple Siliconâ€, and â€œarm64â€. When given the option, you should choose to download the â€œarm64â€/Apple Silicon or the â€œUniversal versionsâ€”if that choice doesnâ€™t exist, then you can choose theâ€x86â€ version which will run in â€œemulated modeâ€, which will result in a slight performance penalty.





Operating system (OS)
We strongly suggest to run the latest version of the operating system (OS) available for your laptop.






Warning



If you update or upgrade your OS you do so on your own risk!


In general, there are many good reasons to update your OS. Some of the software tools or their functionality used in our tutorials will only work on more recent OS versions. Updating your OS will also ensure that you have the latest security updates installed and help prevent unauthorized access to your computer.
There a two main reasons that would prevent you from updating your OS:

Your hardware would not support the updated OS.
Some of your software you depend on might not work on a newer OS.


WindowsmacOS


The latest version of Windows 11 available is 24H2 (build 26100.6584). See here on how to update your Windows 11 machine to the latest version. If you do not own Windows 11, currently enrolled UBC students with a valid CWL account qualify for one license of Windows 11 Education.


The latest version of macOS is Tahoe 16.0. Check your current version of macOS. If you do not have the latest version, follow the upgrade instructions on the Apple support page.
If you cannot upgrade to the latest version, follow these instructions to find the system requirements and upgrade to latest versions available to you. If you need to maintain 32-bit compatibility for any of your software, then upgrade to no higher than macOS 10.14 Mojave.





Terminal
A terminal program allows you to interact with many different programs using a command line interface. Instead of using graphical elements like in a graphical user interface, you type in commands describing what program you want to use and how you want to use it.

WindowsmacOS


The terminal app Terminal comes preinstalled with Windows. Activate the Windows Start menu, start typing â€œterminalâ€ and select the Terminal app by pressing EnterEnter.


The terminal app Terminal comes preinstalled with macOS. Activate Spotlight with Command-SpaceCommand-Space, start typing â€œterminalâ€ and select the Terminal app by pressing EnterEnter.



You will need to open the terminal several times in these instructions to install other programs.


Package manager
A package manager is a program allowing you to install and update programs on your computer, similar to the Microsoft Store on Windows or the App Store on macOS. The main difference of a package manager to these programs is that you use them with a command line interface running in a terminal instead of a graphical user interface.

WindowsmacOS


If you have at least Windows 10 version 1809 (build 17763) or later installed on your machine, you will already have the package manager WinGet available to you. When you use WinGet for the first time, you will be asked to register the Windows Package Manager with the Microsoft Store.






Important



If you cannot update your Windows to a version that supports WinGet, please reach out to the teaching team.



Resources

Use WinGet to install and manage applications




We will use one of the most popular package managers on macOS called Homebrew. Open your Terminal, and then enter the following command:
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
You will be asked to enter the password for your computer:
==> Checking for `sudo` access (which may request your password)...
Enter your password (it is normal that the cursor will not move as you enter characters for a password) and hit EnterEnter.
Next, the installation will install the XCode Command Line Tools:
The XCode Command Line Tools will be installed.
A new window will open with the following prompt:

The â€œxcode-selectâ€ command requires the command line developer tools. Would you like to install the tools now?
Choose Install to download and install the command line developer tools now.â€ Confirm by clicking on â€œInstallâ€.

Afterwards, back in the terminal, you will be informed what steps will be executed:
==> This script will install:
/opt/homebrew/bin/brew
/opt/homebrew/share/doc/homebrew
/opt/homebrew/share/man/man1/brew.1
/opt/homebrew/share/zsh/site-functions/_brew
/opt/homebrew/etc/bash_completion.d/brew
/opt/homebrew
/etc/paths.d/homebrew

Press RETURN/ENTER to continue or any other key to abort:
Confirm with EnterEnter. When the installation is finished, you will be asked to run the following command in the terminal to add Homebrew to your PATH:
echo >> "${HOME}/.zprofile"
echo 'eval "$(/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv)"' >> "${HOME}/.zprofile"
eval "$(/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv)"
Now test if Homebrew works:
brew --version
You should see the following:
Homebrew 4.6.11

Resources

Homebrew Documentation







Python

Installing uv
We will be using Python for a large part of the course, and uv will be our Python package manager. Instead of installing Python separately on our machine, we will use uv to provision us with Python whenever we need to run it.

WindowsmacOS


In the terminal, install uv with Winget:
winget install -e --id=astral-sh.uv


In the terminal install uv with Homebrew:
brew install uv



To check if uv installed successfully, type in the terminal:
uv --version
And you should see something like this
uv 0.8.18 <some-installer-specific-information>

Resources

Installation | uv




marimo
We will be writing our code in a notebook app called marimo. marimo is itself a Python package, so we can use uv to install and run it. In particular, we will use the command uvx which will check if we have the latest version of marimo and everything else necessary to run it, even Python itself!
uvx marimo --version
And you should see:
0.16.0
Even better, try this:
uvx marimo tutorial intro
And your default browser should open a window showing marimo.

For now, letâ€™s shut down marimo by clicking on the red x in the top right corner and then on the â€œShutdownâ€ button.
Now you are ready to run Python code on your local machine!!!

title: Setup: Tech stack
text:
Optional software
If you are interested in using a very common software development tool and platform for version control, check out Git and GitHub. We also have two examples with Zoom or your web browser on how to install and update everyday software with a package manager.

Git and GitHub
We will be using the command line version of Git.

WindowsmacOS


Git is installed as part of Git Bash. Open your terminal, and install Git Bash with
winget install -e --id Git.Git
Restart your terminal.


Open your terminal, and install Git with:
brew install git



In the terminal, type the following to check the Git version:
git --version
You should see something like this if everything is working correctly:
git version 2.51.0

GitHub.com account
Sign up for a free account at GitHub.com if you donâ€™t have one already. Your GitHub.com username is important, so here some advice on picking a username and below an image on how to find it again.



Configuring Git user info
Next, we need to configure Git by telling it your name and email. To do this, provide your name and GitHub email by typing into the terminal:
git config --global user.name "<your-name>"
git config --global user.email "<your-github-email>"






Note



To ensure that you havenâ€™t made a typo in any of the above, you can view your global Git configurations by either opening the configuration file in a text editor (e.g., via the command code ~/.gitconfig) or by typing git config --list --global. You can quit this view by just pressing the q key on your keyboard.




Create your GitHub â€œPersonal Access Tokenâ€
This is a bit tricky, so please make sure you follow these directions carefully.

Start creating a personal access token (PAT) on GitHub.com either by

Clicking this link: https://github.com/settings/tokens/new
Navigating to your tokens by following these steps:

Log in to GitHub.com
Click your picture in the top right and select â€œSettingsâ€
Click on â€œDeveloper Settingsâ€
Click on â€œPersonal access tokensâ€ and then on â€œTokens (classic)â€
Click â€œGenerate new tokenâ€


Give the token a name in the note field, for example, DSCI 221
Choose for expiration â€œCustomâ€ and set the date to the end of this term: 2026-04-10
Set the scope of the token to the â€œrepoâ€ level (see image below):



Personal access token settings


Click â€œGenerate new tokenâ€
Copy the token that is shown to you. It is essentially a password for apps on your computer (for example, Git) to enable them to take actions on GitHub.com for you (in this case, clone a private repository to your computer). Treat this password like any other of your other passwords, so donâ€™t share your token with anyone.
Save this token somewhere safe on your computer, such as a password manager. You will not be able to come back to this page to get your token. If you forget or lose a token, you can just delete that token on GitHub.com where you manage all existing tokens and create another one: https://github.com/settings/tokens




Clone your first repository on your computer
Open the terminal, and then run the following command:
git clone https://github.com/firasm/test.git
Hopefully, if things work, you should be able to see a new folder created at that location. We will be talking more about what exactly you did over the next week and a bit, donâ€™t worry!






Tip



If after running the code above, you see the error message:
fatal: destination path 'test' already exists and is not an empty directory. 
It means that you already attempted a clone before, and there is already a directory called test where you are trying to clone this repository. You will first need to delete that directory to try again. Open an Explorer (Windows) or Finder (macOS) window on your computer, navigate to the directory, right click the test directory and delete it. Alternatively, from the command line you can try:
rm -rf test
which will â€œremoveâ€ (using the rm command) the directory called test. The- is to specify additional options: r means â€œrecursivelyâ€ for all the files in the directory, and f means â€œforceâ€ which means donâ€™t ask me for confirmation after deleting each file and folder.





Zoom
So far, we have been using the package manager to install software development tools. We can use the package manager to install other everyday software making it easier to find the correct version for your hardware or update to the latest release. For example, you might attend office hours or a livestream using Zoom Workplace and you should install the Zoom client locally on your machine.

WindowsmacOS


In your terminal, use WinGet to install Zoom:
winget install -e --id Zoom.Zoom


In your terminal, use Homebrew to install Zoom:
brew install --cask zoom



It is important that you have the most recent version of Zoom installed, as we will be using many of the features that are only available in more recent versions. The latest version of Zoom is 6.6.0 (64511). For a lot of software, there is an option to check for updates.

A package manager can directly update any software you have installed with it.

WindowsmacOS


winget upgrade -e --id Zoom.Zoom


brew upgrade --cask zoom









Important



Please note that if you have been relying on the â€œweb versionâ€ of Zoom that works only in a browser, this will not work for this course! Please make sure to download the Zoom desktop client for your operating system to fully participate in the course.




Web browser
You are welcome to use most modern browsers that have a WebKit or Gecko backend. Safari (Mac only), Firefox, Vivaldi, Brave, Edge are all recommended. Google Chrome is not recommended because of the well-documented privacy and tracking issues with Google.
Optional: try to install the browser also with the package manager! Use this website to find the install instruction for the browser of your choice:

WindowsmacOS


winget.run | Finding winget packages made simple.


Homebrew Formulae

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
The Scene
An algorithm was running, but we paused it mid-execution.
Your job: figure out what it was doing and where it stopped.

â€œThink of this like a crime scene investigation. The clues are in the state.â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Puzzle 1: Find Maximum


def mystery1(arr):
    result = arr[0]
    for i in range(1, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] > result:
            result = arr[i]
    return result




0
1
2
3
4
5
6




7
3
9
2
5
1
8



Variables: result = 9

Q1: What iteration is i about to start?
Q2: What does result represent?

â€œPause and think. What value of i would give us result = 9?â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
The Solution










i = 3 (about to examine index 3)
result = 9 = maximum of arr[0:3] = maximum of [7, 3, 9]

The Invariant: At iteration \(i\), result holds the maximum of arr[0:i].

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Why This Works
The invariant tells us:

At i = 1: result = max of arr[0:1] = max of [7] = 7 âœ“
At i = 2: result = max of arr[0:2] = max of [7, 3] = 7 âœ“
At i = 3: result = max of arr[0:3] = max of [7, 3, 9] = 9 âœ“

The frozen state is consistent with the invariant at i = 3.

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Puzzle 2: Counting


def mystery2(arr):
    count = 0
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        if arr[i] > 5:
            count += 1
    return count




0
1
2
3
4
5
6




4
8
2
7
1
9
3



Variables: count = 2

Q1: What iteration is i about to start?
Q2: State the invariant.

â€œWhich elements > 5 have we seen? 8 at index 1, 7 at index 3. Thatâ€™s 2 elements. So i = 4.â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
The Solution










Elements > 5 in arr[0:4] = [4, 8, 2, 7]: 8 and 7 â†’ count = 2
i = 4

The Invariant: At iteration \(i\), count equals the number of elements > 5 in arr[0:i].

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Puzzle 3: Partitioning


def mystery3(arr):
    pivot = arr[0]
    left = 1
    for right in range(1, len(arr)):
        if arr[right] < pivot:
            arr[left], arr[right] = arr[right], arr[left]
            left += 1
    arr[0], arr[left - 1] = arr[left - 1], arr[0]
    return left - 1

Original: [5, 8, 2, 9, 1, 7, 3]



0
1
2
3
4
5
6




5
2
1
9
8
7
3



pivot = 5, left = 3

Q1: What iteration is right about to start?
Q2: Describe whatâ€™s in arr[1:left] and arr[left:right].

â€œThis is trickier. Notice: arr[1:3] = [2, 1] â€” both < 5. arr[3:?] = ?â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text: The Visualization

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
The Solution

right = 5 (about to examine index 5, which has value 7)
arr[1:left] = arr[1:3] = [2, 1] â€” all < pivot (5)
arr[left:right] = arr[3:5] = [9, 8] â€” all >= pivot (5)

The Invariant (at iteration right):

arr[1:left] contains elements < pivot
arr[left:right] contains elements >= pivot
arr[right:] is unexamined


â€œThis is the partition step from quicksort! The invariant maintains two regions.â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
How to Find Invariants

Look at the loop variable: What does i (or right, etc.) represent?
Look at the accumulated state: What has result, count, left captured so far?
State the relationship: â€œAt iteration \(i\), [variable] holds [property of arr[0:i]]â€
Verify: Does the frozen state match your invariant?

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Common Invariant Patterns



Pattern
Example Invariant




Accumulation
â€œtotal = sum of arr[0:i]â€


Extremum
â€œmax_val = maximum of arr[0:i]â€


Counting
â€œcount = number of X in arr[0:i]â€


Search
â€œIf target exists, itâ€™s in arr[lo:hi+1]â€


Partition
â€œarr[0:left] satisfies P, arr[left:i] doesnâ€™tâ€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Puzzle 4


def mystery4(arr):
    total = 0
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        total += arr[i] * arr[i]
    return total

Variables: total = 14

Q1: What is i? Q2: State the invariant.

â€œThink: 2Â² + 3Â² + 1Â² = 4 + 9 + 1 = 14. So i = 3.â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Solution 4
\(2^2 + 3^2 + 1^2 = 4 + 9 + 1 = 14\)
So i = 3 (about to process index 3).
Invariant: At iteration \(i\), total = sum of squares of arr[0:i].

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Puzzle 5
def mystery5(arr, target):
    lo, hi = 0, len(arr) - 1
    while lo <= hi:
        mid = (lo + hi) // 2
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            lo = mid + 1
        else:
            hi = mid - 1
    return -1
Frozen state: lo = 5, hi = 9, target = 72

Q1: What just happened? Q2: State the invariant.

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Solution 5

Weâ€™re searching for 72
lo = 5, hi = 9 means weâ€™re looking in arr[5:10] = [23, 38, 56, 72, 91]
Previous mid was 4 (value 16 < 72), so we set lo = 5

Invariant: If target is in arr, then target is in arr[lo:hi+1].

â€œWe narrowed from the full array to indices 5-9. The invariant says: if 72 exists, itâ€™s in this range. (And it is â€” at index 8.)â€

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Debugging with Invariants
When your code doesnâ€™t work:

State your invariant (what should be true?)
Print the state at each iteration
Find where the invariant breaks

The bug is where reality diverges from the invariant.

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
The Invariant as Compass

â€œWhen lost, check the invariant.â€


Unsure about an edge case? â†’ Does it maintain the invariant?
Code gives wrong answer? â†’ Where does the invariant fail?
Writing new code? â†’ What invariant do I want to maintain?

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
What We Learned

Invariants are discoverable from frozen states
The pattern: â€œAt iteration \(i\), [variable] holds [property of data seen so far]â€
Common types: accumulation, extremum, counting, search range, partition
The detective method: Look at loop variable, look at accumulated state, state the relationship

title: The Invariant Detective
text:
Next Time
Recursion: When the function calls itself.
Spoiler: Recursion has invariants too â€” we call them recursive properties.

title: Binary Search
text:
The Game
Iâ€™m thinking of a number between 0 and 63.
You can ask yes/no questions.
Whatâ€™s your guaranteed winning strategy?

â€œHow many questions do you need?â€

title: Binary Search
text:
How Many Questions?
Start with \(n = 64\) possibilities (0 to 63).
After each question: \(n \to n/2\)
Questions needed: \(\log_2(64) = 6\)

â€œ6 questions for 64 possibilities. Thatâ€™s the power of halving.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Letâ€™s Play!
Iâ€™m thinking of a number between 0 and 63.
You can ask yes/no questions.

title: Binary Search
text:
The Problem
Given a sorted array and a target value, find the targetâ€™s index (or determine itâ€™s not there).



0
1
2
3
4
5

2

Find target = 23.

â€œThe array must be sorted. Thatâ€™s the precondition.â€

title: Binary Search
Binary Search
Binary Search

Tracing Binary Search

1
2

Find target = 23:

lo=0, hi=9, mid=4 â†’ arr[4]=16 < 23 â†’ lo=5
lo=5, hi=9, mid=7 â†’ arr[7]=56 > 23 â†’ hi=6
lo=5, hi=6, mid=5 â†’ arr[5]=23 âœ“ â†’ return 5


â€œThree comparisons instead of six. At scale, the difference is dramatic.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The 17-Year Bug

â€œIâ€™ve assigned binary search in courses at Bell Labs and IBMâ€¦ and Iâ€™ve studied their solutionsâ€¦ In the history of this exercise, only about ten percent of professional programmers have gotten the program right.â€
â€” Jon Bentley, Programming Pearls (1986)

The first correct binary search was published in 1946.
The first bug-free implementation? 1962.

â€œEven experts get it wrong. The loop invariant helps us get it right.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Invariant
Invariant: If target is in arr, then target is in arr[lo:hi+1].
Equivalently: We havenâ€™t excluded any index where target could be.

â€œThis is the â€˜searchâ€™ pattern: the answer is still in the remaining range.â€
â€œThe invariant holds at any point we might exit the loop.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Base Case (Initialization)
Before the first iteration: lo = 0, hi = len(arr) - 1
arr[lo:hi+1] = arr[0:len(arr)] = entire array
If target is in arr, itâ€™s in arr[lo:hi+1]. âœ“

â€œWe start with the full array. The invariant holds trivially.â€

title: Binary Search
section: Key Fact: mid is Always Valid
text:
Key Fact: mid is Always Valid









Since lo <= hi (loop condition) and mid = (lo + hi) // 2:
\[\texttt{lo} \leq \texttt{mid} \leq \texttt{hi}\]
This means arr[mid] is always a valid access inside the loop.

â€œThis is crucial for all three cases. We can safely access arr[mid] because mid is always in bounds.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Inductive Step: Case 1 (Found it)
arr[mid] == target â†’ we return mid.
Since lo <= mid <= hi, we know mid is in the search range.
We found the target and return its index. âœ“

â€œFound it. The key fact tells us mid is valid, and we verified arr[mid] == target.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Inductive Step: Case 2
arr[mid] < target









Setting lo = mid + 1 excludes only indices where target canâ€™t be. âœ“

â€œWeâ€™re safe to narrow the range because weâ€™re only excluding impossible locations.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Inductive Step: Case 3
arr[mid] > target









Setting hi = mid - 1 excludes only indices where target canâ€™t be. âœ“

â€œSame reasoning. We only narrow the range safely.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Termination (Exit via lo > hi)
The loop exits when lo > hi.
At this exit point, arr[lo:hi+1] is empty.
The invariant says: if target is in arr, itâ€™s in this empty range.
But nothing is in an empty range.
Therefore: target is not in arr. Return -1. âˆ

â€œThe invariant holds at this exit point too â€” it just tells us target isnâ€™t there.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Proof in One Slide
Theorem: binary_search(arr, target) returns the index of target if present, else -1.
Proof: By induction on iteration count.

Invariant: If target âˆˆ arr, then target âˆˆ arr[lo:hi+1]
Base case: Initially, full array satisfies invariant âœ“
Inductive step: Each case either exits correctly or safely shrinks range âœ“
Termination: At exit, invariant \(\Rightarrow\) correct answer âˆ

title: Binary Search
text:
Common Mistakes
# Bug 1: Wrong comparison
while lo < hi:  # Should be lo <= hi
    ...

# Bug 2: Wrong update
lo = mid        # Should be mid + 1
hi = mid        # Should be mid - 1

# Bug 3: Integer overflow (in C/Java)
mid = (lo + hi) / 2  # Can overflow!
# Fix: mid = lo + (hi - lo) / 2

â€œBug 1: misses the case where lo == hi. Bug 2: can cause infinite loop. Bug 3: famous Java bug, discovered in 2006 in Arrays.binarySearch!â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Java Bug (2006)
// This was in java.util.Arrays for 9 years!
int mid = (low + high) / 2;  // OVERFLOW BUG
When low + high > Integer.MAX_VALUE, this overflows.
Fix:
int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;

â€œJoshua Bloch, who wrote the code, wrote about this bug. Even Google engineers get binary search wrong.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Invariant Saves You
When youâ€™re unsure about an edge case, ask:

â€œDoes this maintain the invariant?â€


lo = mid + 1: Does this exclude only impossible locations? Yes.
hi = mid - 1: Does this exclude only impossible locations? Yes.
lo <= hi: When does the search space become empty? When lo > hi.


â€œThe invariant is your compass. When lost, check the invariant.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Worst-Case Running Time
Each iteration:

Constant work (comparisons, arithmetic)
Range shrinks by half: \((hi - lo + 1) \to \lfloor(hi - lo + 1)/2\rfloor\)

How many halvings until range is empty?
\(\log_2(n)\)
Worst case: \(\Theta(\log n)\)

â€œThe halving is the key. Thatâ€™s what gives us the logarithm.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Scale Comparison



\(n\)
Linear Search
Binary Search




1,000
1,000
10


1,000,000
1,000,000
20


1,000,000,000
1,000,000,000
30




â€œA billion elements, 30 comparisons. Thatâ€™s the power of \(O(\log n)\).â€

title: Binary Search
text: Racing Them

title: Binary Search
text:
The Race







â€œLinear grows with n.Â Binary barely budges. Thatâ€™s \(O(n)\) vs \(O(\log n)\).â€

title: Binary Search
text:
The Precondition
Binary search requires the array to be sorted.
What if itâ€™s not sorted?







â€œGarbage in, garbage out. The invariant assumes sorted order.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
When to Use Binary Search
Use binary search when:

Data is sorted (or can be sorted once, searched many times)
Random access is \(O(1)\) (arrays, not linked lists)
You need to find a specific value

Donâ€™t use when:

Data is unsorted and searched only once
Data structure doesnâ€™t support random access
You need to find all occurrences


â€œSorting costs \(O(n \log n)\). If you only search once, linear search wins.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
What We Learned

Binary search finds a target in \(\Theta(\log n)\) time (vs \(\Theta(n)\) for linear)
The invariant: â€œIf target exists, itâ€™s in arr[lo:hi+1]â€
The proof: Init, Maintenance (3 cases), Termination
The bugs: Off-by-one errors, infinite loops, integer overflow
The precondition: Array must be sorted

title: Binary Search
text:
Wednesday
Recursion: When the function calls itself.

Thinking recursively
Binary search, recursively
The fractal coastline puzzle


â€œBinary search can also be written recursively. Weâ€™ll explore that Wednesday.â€

title: Binary Search
text:
Questions?

Binary search: \(\Theta(\log n)\)
The invariant makes it correct.
The halving makes it fast.

title: Introduction to Recursion
section: ğŸµ On the first day before breakâ€¦
text:
ğŸµ On the first day before breakâ€¦
On the first day before break, my prof gave to meâ€¦
A latte from Loafe

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
ğŸµ On the thirteenth dayâ€¦



Thirteen moments of zen
Twelve grateful neurons
Eleven Piazza posts

Six hours of sleep

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Question
After 13 days, how many gifts did I receive in total?

Day 1: 1 gift
Day 2: 1 + 2 = 3 gifts total
Day 3: 1 + 2 + 3 = 6 gifts total
â€¦
Day 13: 1 + 2 + 3 + â€¦ + 13 = ?

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Sum
\[1 + 2 + 3 + \ldots + n = \sum_{k=1}^{n} k\]
For \(n = 13\):
\[1 + 2 + 3 + \ldots + 13 = 91 \text{ gifts}\]
Youâ€™ve seen the closed form: \(\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Proving the Closed Form
Claim: \(f(n) = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\) where \(f(n) = 1 + 2 + \ldots + n\)
Weâ€™ll prove this by induction.

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Proof by Induction
Consider an arbitrary \(n >= 0\). Then consider the following cases:
Case 1, \(n = 0\) (base case): \(f(0) = 0 = \frac{0 \cdot 1}{2}\) âœ“
Case 2, \(n>0\) (inductive case):
Assume for any \(0 < j < n\), \(f(j) = \frac{j(j+1)}{2}\) (Inductive Hypothesis)
\(f(n) = f(n-1) + n\) by definition. \(f(n-1) = \frac{(n-1)(n)}{2}\) by IH, since \(n-1 < n\). \(f(n) = \frac{(n-1)(n)}{2} + n = \frac{(n)(n+1)}{2}\) by algebra. âœ“

â€œNotice: the inductive step assumes f(k) works and uses it. Just like recursion!â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
A Different Way to Think
How many gifts on day 13?

Whatever I had on day 12, plus 13 more.
\[f(13) = f(12) + 13\]

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Recursive Definition
\[f(n) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } n = 0 \\ f(n-1) + n & \text{if } n > 0 \end{cases}\]
Base case: \(f(0) = 0\) (zero days = zero gifts)
Recursive case: \(f(n) = f(n-1) + n\)

â€œThis is a recursive definition. The function is defined in terms of itself.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Induction = Recursion



Induction
Recursion




Consider arbitrary \(n \geq 0\)
def f(n):


Case \(n = 0\): prove directly
if n == 0: return 0


Case \(n > 0\): assume \(P(j)\) for \(j < n\)
Trust f(n-1) works


Prove \(P(n)\) using IH
Compute f(n) using f(n-1)



Same structure. Same reasoning.

â€œIf you can prove it by induction, you can compute it by recursion. Theyâ€™re the same thing.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text: Visualizing the Sum

title: Introduction to Recursion
section: The Recursive Structure: Peel Bottom Row
text:
The Recursive Structure: Peel Bottom Row










â€œThe triangle with n rows = the triangle with n-1 rows + n more dots on the bottom.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Peel Two Rows?









\[f(n) = f(n-2) + (n-1) + n\]
We can peel off any number of rows!

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Recursive Code
def triangle(n):
    if n == 0:
        return 0
    return triangle(n - 1) + n
Compare to the math:
\[f(n) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } n = 0 \\ f(n-1) + n & \text{if } n > 0 \end{cases}\]

â€œThe code is a direct translation of the math. Base case, recursive case.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Trust the Recursion Fairy
When you write triangle(n - 1), trust that it works.
This is exactly like relying on the inductive hypothesis in a proof.
Donâ€™t trace through every call. Just ask:

Does my base case return the right thing?
If triangle(n-1) magically gives me the right answer, does my code use it correctly?


â€œThe recursion fairy handles the recursive call. You just handle your level. Same as induction: assume P(k) holds, prove P(k+1).â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Same Triangle, Different View
What if we split the triangle differently?

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Quadrant Decomposition
For \(n\) rows (where \(n\) is even):

Blue: Top triangle with \(n/2\) rows â†’ \(f(n/2)\) dots
Red: Bottom-right triangle with \(n/2\) rows â†’ \(f(n/2)\) dots
Green: Rectangle of size \((n/2) \times (n/2)\) â†’ \((n/2)^2\) dots

\[f(n) = 2 \cdot f(n/2) + (n/2)^2\]

â€œSame problem, different recursive structure!â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text: Split Anywhere!

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The General Decomposition
For any \(0 < k < n\):
\[f(n) = f(n-k) + k \cdot (n-k) + f(k)\]

Blue: Top triangle with \(n-k\) rows â†’ \(f(n-k)\) dots
Green: Rectangle of size \(k \times (n-k)\) â†’ \(k(n-k)\) dots
Red: Bottom-right triangle with \(k\) rows â†’ \(f(k)\) dots


The insight: There are infinitely many valid decompositions!

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
But Waitâ€¦ Base Cases?
With \(f(n) = f(n-k) + k(n-k) + f(k)\) and \(k = 5\):

\(f(8) = f(3) + 5 \cdot 3 + f(5)\)
\(f(5) = f(0) + 5 \cdot 0 + f(5)\) â€¦ infinite loop!


We need base cases for \(f(0), f(1), \ldots, f(k)\).


Lesson: Your base cases must cover everything your recursion can reach.

â€œThe quadrant decomposition (k = n/2) only needs f(0) and f(1). This k=5 split needs base cases for 0 through 5. More base cases = more work to verify.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Divide-and-Conquer Code
def triangle_fast(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return n
    half = n // 2
    return 2 * triangle_fast(half) + half * half

Does it compute the same thing?

title: Introduction to Recursion

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Which is Faster?
Both compute the same answer.
But the recursive structures are different:

triangle(n): makes \(n\) recursive calls
triangle_fast(n): makes \(\log_2(n)\) recursive calls


Letâ€™s race them!

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
The Race







â€œSame answer. Wildly different performance. Thatâ€™s the power of choosing the right decomposition.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Why So Different?
triangle(n): \(f(n) = f(n-1) + n\)

Recursion depth: \(n\)
Total calls: \(n\)

triangle_fast(n): \(f(n) = 2 \cdot f(n/2) + (n/2)^2\)

Recursion depth: \(\log_2(n)\)
Total calls: \(\log_2(n)\)


â€œLinear depth vs logarithmic depth. At n=50000, thatâ€™s 50000 vs ~16.â€

title: Introduction to Recursion
text:
Recursion is About Decomposition
The same problem can have multiple recursive structures.
Different structures lead to different code and different performance.

This is the heart of algorithm design.

â€œThis is why we study algorithms, not just â€˜how to codeâ€™. The structure matters.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Trusting Your Code
def ________________(arr, a):
    ret = a
    for i in range(a + 1, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] < arr[ret]:
            ret = i
    return ret

What does this function do?
Does it work?

â€œYou might say â€˜I tested it.â€™ But testing checks examples, not all inputs.â€
â€œWe want mathematical certainty.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Testing Is Not Proof
Testing: â€œIt worked on these 10 inputs.â€

â€œDijkstra: â€˜Testing shows the presence of bugs, not their absence.â€™â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Key Insight
A loop is just induction in disguise.



Induction
Loop Invariant




Base case
Initialization


Inductive step
Maintenance


â€œFor all \(n\)â€

â€œYou already know induction from discrete math. Loop invariants are the same idea applied to code.â€

title: Correctness
text:
What Is an Invariant?
An invariant is a property that remains true.
â€œNo matter how many times the loop runs, this statement stays true.â€

â€œThe word â€˜invariantâ€™ = â€˜not varyingâ€™ = stays the same.â€

Step
What to show

Inductive step
Assuming \(P(j)\) for all \(j\) in domain where \(j < i\), show \(P(i)\)


Termination

â€œThis is just induction on the iteration count. The domain of i depends on your loop â€” it might be \(\{0, \ldots, n\}\) or \(\{a+1, \ldots, n\}\) or something else.â€

Invariant: At iteration \(i\) (for \(i \in \{a+1, \ldots, n\}\)), ret holds the index of the minimum value in arr[a:i].

â€œThe hard part is finding the right invariant. Once you have it, the proof often falls into place.â€

def find_min(arr, a):
    """Return index of minimum value in arr[a:]"""
    ret = a
    for i in range(a + 1, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] < arr[ret]:
            ret = i

At the first iteration, i = a+1 and ret = a.
The invariant claims ret is the index of the min in arr[a:a+1].
arr[a:a+1] contains only arr[a], and ret = a is its index. âœ“

â€œThis is the base case. Weâ€™ve â€˜seenâ€™ only arr[a], and ret points to it.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Step 3: Inductive Step
def find_min(arr, a):
    """Return index of minimum value in arr[a:]"""
    ret = a
    for i in range(a + 1, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] < arr[ret]:
            ret = i
    return ret

IH: Assume the invariant holds at the start of iteration \(i\): ret is the index of min in arr[a:i].
During iteration \(i\), we compare arr[i] to arr[ret]:

Case 1: arr[i] < arr[ret] â†’ we set ret = i, the new min
Case 2: arr[i] >= arr[ret] â†’ we keep ret, still the min

Either way, after iteration \(i\), ret is the index of min in arr[a:i+1]. âœ“

â€œThe two cases correspond to the if/else. In both cases, ret ends up pointing to the minimum of arr[a:i+1], which is the invariant for iteration i+1.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Step 4: Termination
Loop terminates when i = n (after processing the last element).
Plug into invariant: ret is index of min in arr[a:n].
But arr[a:n] is exactly arr[a:].
Therefore: ret is the index of the minimum in arr[a:]. âˆ

â€œAt i = n, ret is min of arr[a:n] = arr[a:].â€
â€œThe âˆ (tombstone/halmos) marks the end of a proof.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Proof in One Slide
Theorem: find_min(arr, a) returns the index of the minimum value in arr[a:].
Proof: By induction on iteration count.

Invariant: At iteration \(i\) (for \(i \in \{a+1, \ldots, n\}\)), ret is index of min in arr[a:i]
Base case: At \(i = a+1\), ret = a is min of arr[a:a+1] âœ“
Inductive step: If true at start of iteration \(i\), loop body restores it for \(i+1\) âœ“
Termination: Plug in \(i = n\) â†’ ret is min of arr[a:n] = arr[a:] âˆ

title: Correctness
text:
The Code
def array_sum(arr):
    total = 0
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        total += arr[i]
    return total
Whatâ€™s the invariant?

â€œPause the video and try to state the invariant before I reveal it.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Invariant
Invariant: At iteration \(i\) (for \(i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\)), total equals the sum of arr[0:i].

â€œThis captures what weâ€™re building up as we go. Here i ranges from 0 to n.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Proof (Quick Version)

Base case: At \(i = 0\), total = 0 = sum of arr[0:0]. âœ“
Inductive step: Assume invariant holds at start of iteration \(i\): total = sum of arr[0:i].
During iteration \(i\), we add arr[i] to total.
After iteration \(i\): total = sum of arr[0:i] + arr[i] = sum of arr[0:i+1]. âœ“
Termination: Plug in \(i = n\) â†’ total = sum of arr[0:n] = sum of all. âˆ


â€œWith practice, these proofs become quick sketches, not page-long arguments.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Selection Sort
def selection_sort(arr):
    for a in range(len(arr)):
        min_idx = find_min(arr, a)
        arr[a], arr[min_idx] = arr[min_idx], arr[a]

This uses our find_min helper!
Quick check: running time?


â€œSelection sort: repeatedly find the minimum of the unsorted portion and swap it to the front.â€
â€œNotice it calls find_min(arr, a) â€” exactly the function we just proved correct.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Decomposition Principle
We already proved find_min(arr, a) returns the index of the minimum in arr[a:].
Now we can use that fact without re-proving it.

Prove small pieces. Compose them into bigger proofs.


â€œThis is the software engineering principle of decomposition, applied to proofs.â€
â€œYou donâ€™t re-derive addition every time you use it. Same idea here.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Selection Sort Invariant
Invariant: At iteration \(a\) (for \(a \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\)), arr[0:a] is sorted and contains the \(a\) smallest elements.

â€œThe first a elements are sorted AND theyâ€™re the smallest a elements overall.â€
â€œBoth parts matter â€” sorted isnâ€™t enough; they have to be the right elements.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Proof

Base case: At \(a = 0\), arr[0:0] is empty. âœ“ (Trivially sorted, trivially smallest.)
Inductive step: Assume invariant holds at start of iteration \(a\): arr[0:a] is sorted and contains the \(a\) smallest elements.
During iteration \(a\):

find_min(arr, a) returns the index of the minimum in arr[a:] (by our earlier proof!)
After the swap, arr[a] holds the \((a+1)\)-th smallest element

After iteration \(a\): arr[0:a+1] is sorted and contains the \(a+1\) smallest elements. âœ“
Termination: Plug in \(a = n\) â†’ arr[0:n] is sorted. âˆ


â€œSee how we just used the find_min correctness? We didnâ€™t re-prove it.â€
â€œThis is the power of decomposition: prove once, use everywhere.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Lesson
Decomposition is good system engineering.








Software
Proofs
Data Pipelines




Write small, tested functions
Prove small helper lemmas
Build validated transformations


Compose into larger programs
Compose into larger proofs
Chain into workflows


Reuse without re-implementing
Reuse without re-proving
Reuse without re-validating




â€œWhen you write find_min as a separate function, youâ€™re setting yourself up for cleaner code AND cleaner proofs.â€
â€œSame for data science: build a cleaning step you trust, a feature extraction step you trust, then compose them. You donâ€™t re-check the cleaning every time you use it.â€

title: Correctness
text:
The Art
Stating the invariant is often the hardest part.
Strategy: Ask â€œWhat property do I maintain that leads to my answer?â€

â€œThe invariant should connect the loopâ€™s progress to the final goal.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Common Patterns



Algorithm Type
Invariant Pattern




Accumulation
â€œvar holds result for elements seen so farâ€


Search
â€œIf target exists, itâ€™s in the remaining rangeâ€


Partition
â€œElements before \(i\) satisfy property Pâ€


Two-pointer
â€œAnswer is not in the excluded regionâ€




â€œWednesday: weâ€™ll use the â€˜searchâ€™ pattern for binary search.â€

title: Correctness
text:
Design, Not Just Proof
Loop invariants arenâ€™t just for proving code correct.
Theyâ€™re a design tool.

â€œWhat should be true at each step?â€

If you canâ€™t state the invariant, you might not understand your own algorithm.

â€œWhen youâ€™re stuck debugging, ask: whatâ€™s my invariant? Often the bug is that youâ€™re not maintaining it.â€

title: Correctness
text:
A Warning
A wrong invariant can â€œproveâ€ incorrect code correct.
The invariant must be:

True (actually holds at each iteration)
Strong enough (implies correctness at termination)
Preserved (maintained by the loop body)


â€œYou canâ€™t just make up any statement. It has to capture the actual behavior.â€

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description and Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Define and articulate the functionality of classic data structures such as Stacks, Queues, Dictionaries, Priority Queues, etc. by their Abstract Data Type (ADT).
Design algorithms and structures to implement novel ADTs based on properties of the data and intended use of the data, using object-oriented problem decomposition.
Implement classic and novel data structures in modern Python, based upon lists, dictionaries, trees, and graphs.
Analyze the efficiency (time and space) of algorithms and data structures using asymptotic notation.
Justify algorithmic choices using iterative and recursive proofs of correctness.
Evaluate asymptotic time and space trade-offs between implementation options.
Identify the structures and algorithms necessary for solving complex problems.
Synthesize and apply algorithmic and analytical design choices to form complete software solutions of classic problems.

title: Syllabus
text:
Lecture Material and Course Content
DSCI 221 meets officially MWF at 11am in MacMillan 158. After the first week, the schedule shifts:

Monday: In-person lecture (MCML 158)
Tuesday: Online video lecture (asynchronous)
Wednesday: In-person lecture (MCML 158)
Friday: No class (after week 1)

Class meetings will be a mixture of theoretical narrative, worked examples, and problem-solving exercises. You will learn about algorithmic efficiency, correctness proofs, and the design of data structuresâ€”applying these ideas to problems that arise in data science contexts.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Requirements
Deliverables for the course include the following components:

Programming Assignments (PAs) â€” Three significant programming projects where youâ€™ll implement data structures and algorithms. Due approximately every 4-5 weeks.
Homework (HWs) â€” Three written assignments focusing on algorithm analysis, correctness proofs, and problem-solving. Due approximately every 4-5 weeks.
Labs â€” Ten weekly lab exercises providing hands-on practice with the concepts from lecture. Labs are completed on PrairieLearn.
Examlets â€” Five 50-minute assessments completed in the Computer-Based Testing Facility (CBTF). These are self-scheduled within a window and cover both conceptual and coding questions.
Final Exam â€” A comprehensive exam, self-scheduled in the CBTF during the final exam period.
